Welcome to Hamilton County, Texas

Hamilton County was founded in 1856 and the County seat is Hamilton.  It is located in the Edwards Plateau in Central Texas and bounded on the north by Comanche, Erath, and Bosque counties, on the west by Mills County, and on the south by Lampasas and Coryell counties. The county was named for James Hamilton, a South Carolina governor who invested some $216,000 in gold to finance the Texas struggle for independence from Mexico.

Hamilton County covers approximately 844 square miles and has a population of around 8,500.  The two largest towns are Hamilton and Hico.

How to find us.

Hamilton County Courthouse
102 N Rice Street
Hamilton, TX 76531

The County Information Resources Agency (CIRA) provides technology services and resources to more than 140 counties and local governments in Texas, including email and website services. Learn more about this organization and how to join.

TAC CIRA Email Service: How to Deal with SPAM & Phishing Emails

Recently, there has been an internet-wide increase in SPAM and phishing emails. Phishing emails attempt to trick the recipient by disguising the sender as a colleague, elected official or known person, in an attempt to penetrate networks, spread malware to or steal information from the email recipient. This is a widespread issue that is affecting state agencies, schools and municipalities.

This guide discusses the steps you and your staff when encountering SPAM or phishing emails.

Click here to view the TAC CIRA Email Service SPAM and Phishing Guide

County Jobs Roundup

Counties are now able to post on TAC's website in addition to their own. This will allow for greater visibility of your job offerings. Contact TAC Membership Services for more information at TACMembership@county.org or call Frank Baca at (800) 456-5974.


Availability of Bilingual Online Voting Materials for Spanish Speaking Voters

The ACLU has recently contacted Texas counties regarding their compliance with the Texas Secretary of State’s Election Advisory No. 2018-28 which requires all election materials to also be provided in Spanish. Please be certain that you are complying with state and federal law by posting accurately translated Spanish versions of all election-related content on your site.

Please view an updated list of mandated website posting requirements for Texas Counties to ensure your website is in compliance. Please consult your county attorney with any questions about a particular mandate.
